人为温室气体引起的气候变化，已经成为当今和未来世界经济主要的风险之一，影响到社会财富、资源、能源价格以及投资评估和公司价值估价。全球气候变化背景下兴起的低碳经济，是对工业革命以来全球经济高碳发展模式的“逆动”，是工业革命以来又一个历史大变局。当前，发展低碳经济正成为世界各国寻求可持续发展的重要战略选择。开设相关课程，有利于促进学生了解气候变化与低碳发展，增进环保理念，构建两型社会。日益严重的全球气候变化和环境问题使低碳经济正在成为全球发展的潮流，而日益严重的资源约束，也使我国经济发展方式正在发生深刻的转变。在此背景下，低碳经济、节能减排及生态环境保护不仅是一种经济愿景，一项社会工程，也是非常重要的经济社会研究课题。本课程旨在深入研究气候变化与低碳发展，促进学生对气候变化的科学认识，进一步增强环境危机感，并有效地传播资源节约与环境友好的理念与可能的实践探索方向。

The course International Business focus on (economic) theories of international business related to globalisation, international trade as well as theoretical concepts explaining Foreign Direct Investments (FDI’s). It will learn diplomats to look from different angles at the process of globalisation. It also elaborates on the changing trade and investment patterns we see today compared to a decade ago. Clearly, there is a lot of dynamics in the international environment, including new players such as China and India, a new global middle class that is not situated  in the west anymore, international competition that really becomes global and the emergence and deepening of trading blocs which make a regional strategy for companies as well as governments possible. It is essential to have knowledge about the transformations that are happening in the economic, financial and monetary world and to distinguish structural developments from cyclical developments.The course Dynamics of International Business aims to provide the participants an eclectic international perspective on business and governments, including knowledge, skills and tools that are fine tuned for operating in an international environment.

The course will introduce experimental economics, a method for collecting behavioral data under controlled conditions in the laboratory or in the field. Even though the method is rather well established in Western countries by now, it is still in its infancy in China. Laboratory experiments are an important and valuable tool to complement field studies for a number of reasons: the researcher is able to control the decision environment in a way hardly attainable in a natural setting. Behavioral data are gathered in experimental sessions where only the variable of interest is varied, providing a true ceteris paribus change. Observed differences in behavior can thus be attributed to the modification under study. Different from survey studies, experimental investigations are based on actual decisions associated with monetary rewards that are related to the participants’ choices. Laboratory experiments can serve as a ‘wind tunnel’ before institutional changes are implemented. Finally, experimental economics is well suited for cross-cultural and intercultural research as running experiments with exactly the same design in different countries allows to directly comparing behavior across cultures.
The course provides the main methodological requirements. It introduces basic economics experiments like the Ultimatum, the Dictator and the Trust game and will have students participate in own experiments. Examples of cross-cultural experiments will be given with special emphasis on Germany and China. The course will enable students to start designing their own simple experiments.

Understanding Academic Paper is a course designed  for graduate students  who intend to improve their skills in understanding academic paper in international leading journals in economics and business, and to develop their capability in establishing their research territory. Although English comprehension is important for this course, it is not a language course. It focuses on critical thinking and idea creation. During the course, students learn strategies to improve their comprehension through analyzing models and reading practice. Course topics include paper selecting and identifying, paper structure, main attribute and function of each section of a paper (abstract, introduction, theory, methods, discussion, conclusion and reference), paper generalization, and important elements in academic paper. A few hot topics in international economics and business are addressed as needed. Students receive feedback from the instructor on each reading assignment.  This course suits to small group teaching. The number of students is not more than 30. Students will be expected to work in small groups as well as individually and to have some interactive discussions in class.
From Paris to Lisbon: The Making and Reform of EU Treaties
From Paris to Lisbon: The Making and Reform of EU Treaties

This course will cover the historic development of the treaty foundation of European integration, from the Paris Treaty (1951), which created the European Coal and Steel Community, until the latest important treaty reform, the Lisbon Treaty (2009). This will include the Rome Treaties, which created the European Economic Community and the European Atomic Energy Community in 1957 and the Maastricht Treaty, which created the European Union in 1993. What were the main reasons for these successive treaties? Which institutions did they create? Which common policies did they initiate?What are the alternative political science interpretations of the changes over time?
The EU as a Global Actor
The EU as a Global Actor

The EU has become an important international player, especially in trade and development policies. This started from the beginning of the integration process in the 1950s but has expanded since then. Since the Maastricht Treaty the EU also has endeavored to develop a Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), and the Lisbon Treaty has established a European External Action Service (EEAS), with a kind of foreign minister position. This course will trace these developments, try to explain them and also discuss the limitations of these developments.
Comparative Regional Integration: Europe and Beyond
Comparative Regional Integration: Europe and Beyond

Europe is not the only region in the world where there are efforts of international integration. There is the North American Free Trade Area (NAFTA), the Southern Common Market, MERCOSUR, in South America, ASEAN in South East Asia, and many other regional integration schemes in the world. But the EU remains unique when it comes to creating ‘supranational’ institutions, like the European Commission and European Court of Justice (ECJ) as well as allowing majority votes in the Council of Ministers. What explains the differences between the EU and other integration schemes? The academic literature points to a number of factors: different degrees of economic interdependence, different degrees of power asymmetry among the member countries, various identity factors, including values, etc. This course will look at these different variables and discuss their relative relevance.

This course provides students with a basic introduction to the history and politics of the European Union, as well as to the process of European integration. It assumes no prior knowledge of the topic.

The course International Business focus on (economic) theories of international business related to globalisation, international trade as well as theoretical concepts explaining Foreign Direct Investments (FDI’s). It will learn students to look from different angles at the process of globalisation. It also elaborates on the changing trade and investment patterns we see today compared to a decade ago. Clearly, there is a lot of dynamics in the international environment, including new players such as China and India, a new global middle class that is not situated in the west anymore, international competition that really becomes global and the emergence and deepening of trading blocs which make a regional strategy for companies as well as governments possible. It is essential to have knowledge about the transformations that are happening in the economic, financial and monetary world and to distinguish structural developments from cyclical developments
Macro- Economics: China Compared to The Eu
Macro- Economics: China Compared to The Eu

It is interesting to note that the essentials of economics such as explaining economic growth, development of the exchange rate, and the use of fiscal and monetary policy are more or less the same all over the world. Drivers behind economic growth in China are the same as in countries such as France and Germany…although from another magnitude and intensity. Also the ways governments may counteract economic problems are driven by the same theories in many countries in the world. From this perspective, macro-economics is universal in its approach, although adjustments are needed to adapt to local environment. We will answer the questions what determines economic growth. We will discuss growth performance in China compared to the euro zone. Related to this, we will discuss the various types of policy the government or central bank can use to tackle economic problems of low economic growth, rising unemployment and inflation. Clearly, the focus is on the optimum combination of fiscal policy and monetary policy. Fiscal policy involves altering taxes and government spending. Monetary policy is changing the interest rate. We see government both in China and in the West struggling with the question how much help is needed.

Innovation Economics’ will introduce the undergraduate students into the broad field of modern innovation economics. Innovation economics has gained momentum since the 1990s as an autonomous field in economics qualified by the increasing importance of knowledge and innovation for the competitiveness of firms, regions and economies as well as by the peculiarities of innovations which makes innovation processes difficult to be analyzed in the context of standard industrial economics. It turned out that modern innovation economics has become a field of interdisciplinary research combining besides economists, among others technological historians, economic sociologist, engineers and complexity researchers. In this course students will be made acquainted to the most important concepts, schools, problems and methodologies in the analysis of innovation processes.

The course consists of two parts. In the first part, the characteristics and trends in the international and multinational business activities are shortly analysed on the basis of the latest available data. The theoretical foundations, the determinants of foreign direct investment (FDI) and the internationalisation strategy of firms are studied. The organisational structures (intra-firm relationships) of the multinational enterprises (MNEs) as well as their ownership structure (e.g. joint ventures) and partnerships (i.e. strategic alliances) (inter-firm relationships) are also considered. The second part of the course will discuss the major challenges that are faced by European MNEs when entering foreign (especially Chinese) markets on the basis of case discussion.

Everyone negotiates something every day. Whether it is how to handle an organizational challenge, a takeover or a dispute, successful negotiation means getting what you want without offending the other party. Negotiating is not a one-off activity or a finite set of skills. It is an on-going challenge, which benefits from continual practice, analysis and review. Every negotiation is different, but the basic elements do not change. The tools and techniques provided in this course will assist participants become better negotiators, whether there is one issue or several; two parties or many. This negotiation skills course is a foundation course developed to help undergraduate students in Johns Hopkins University and Uppsala University. This course forms part of a series of negotiation training courses that is developing for students in the European Union and United States.
